channel.title: Comments on: Standards Based Grading – All in, for the new year
channel.description: iteration, making, building, and coding in education

item.title: By: Evan Weinberg
item.dc:creator: Evan Weinberg
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/2012/08/20/standards-based-grading-all-in-for-the-new-year/#comment-96">Kevin Krenz (@kevin_krenz)</a>.
I was going to make this myself - thank you for doing it for me! I completely agree that part of the battle is reassessment. The thing I've wondered about (at least under the old system) is whether the process of writing the reflection/request scares students off from actually doing it. They might reason 'it doesn't affect my grade that much, so I'll just learn it for the test' even though the reflection IS the kick they need to dig in to what they don't understand. I think by committing to this, I am showing students that this reflection IS what I value.
Thank you for sharing!

item.title: By: Kevin Krenz (@kevin_krenz)
item.dc:creator: Kevin Krenz (@kevin_krenz)
item.description: I found that it helped a lot to structure what the students need to do before reassessing. I created this form (http://goo.gl/8UeNc) and told students they needed it approved the day before reassessing. For whatever reason, it greatly increased the number of reassessments, as well as improved the quality of the reassessments.
